perturbation.original_text: If the Investment Adviser is required to reimburse the Fund, the Investment Adviser shall make such payment within 30 days  after each month-end in the amount due the Fund as of each month. If the Fund is required to pay the Investment Adviser the Expense  Waiver, the Fund shall make such payment within 30 days after each month-end.
perturbation.changed_text: If the Investment Adviser is required to reimburse the Fund, the Investment Adviser shall make such payment within 60 days after each quarter-end in the amount due the Fund as of each month. If the Fund is required to pay the Investment Adviser the Expense Waiver, the Fund shall make such payment within 90 days after each fiscal year-end.
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires reimbursements to be made within 30 days after each month-end, which aligns with standard industry practice and regulatory expectations for fund operations. The modification extends these periods to 60 days after each quarter-end for the Investment Adviser's reimbursement and 90 days after each fiscal year-end for the Fund's payment. This creates a potential conflict because such extended payment terms may not provide timely compensation necessary to maintain financial stability and could violate requirements for prompt financial settlements.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Investment Company Act of 1940, specifically provisions related to fair and prompt compensation and financial stability of investment companies. Delayed reimbursement impacts Net Investment Income

perturbation.original_text: This Agreement shall continue in effect for a period of one year from the date of its execution and from year to year thereafter provided such  continuance is specifically approved by a majority of the trustees of the Trust who (i) are not "interested persons" of the Trust or any other party  to this Agreement, as defined in the 1940 Act, and (ii) have no direct or indirect financial interest in the operation of this Agreement ("Non- Interested Trustees"). This Agreement will terminate upon the termination of the Advisory Agreement except the Investment Adviser's Right of  Recovery set forth in section 1.5 herein.
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement shall continue in effect for a period of five years from the date of its execution and from year to year thereafter provided such continuance is specifically approved by a simple majority of the trustees of the Trust, regardless of their interest or relationship to the parties involved. This Agreement will terminate at the discretion of the Investment Advisor.
perturbation.explanation: The original text stipulates annual renewal with approval by disinterested trustees. The modified text extends the initial term to five years and removes the requirement for disinterested trustee approval, only requiring a simple majority of trustees regardless of their conflicts of interest. This could be problematic under the Investment Company Act of 1940, which mandates that certain agreements be reviewed and approved by disinterested parties to protect the interests of the fund and its shareholders.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Investment Company Act of 1940, Section 15(c) and related regulations concerning the approval and renewal of investment advisory and underwriting agreements by disinterested trustees.

perturbation.original_text: The Investment Adviser shall have the option to recover the full amount waived, paid or reimbursed (the Expense  Waiver) by the Investment Adviser on any day on which the Fund's Net Investment Income exceeds zero. In no event, however, shall  the Expense Waiver, or any portion thereof, constitute an obligation of the Fund to the Investment Adviser on any such day unless  the Investment Adviser has expressly exercised its right to recover all or a portion of the Expense Waiver on that day, in which case  such portion of the Expense Waiver elected by the Investment Adviser for recovery that day shall then be due and payable. If, and to  the extent, the payment by the Fund to the Investment Adviser of the Expense Waiver would cause the Fund's Net Investment Income  to fall below zero, such payment shall be deferred until such date on which the
perturbation.changed_text: The Investment Adviser shall have the option to recover 25% of the amount waived, paid or reimbursed (the Expense Waiver) by the Investment Adviser on any day on which the Fund's Net Investment Income exceeds zero. In no event, however, shall the Expense Waiver, or any portion thereof, constitute an obligation of the Fund to the Investment Adviser on any such day unless the Investment Adviser has expressly exercised its right to recover all or a portion of the Expense Waiver within one year of its waiver, in which case such portion of the Expense Waiver elected by the Investment Adviser for recovery that day shall then be due and payable. If, and to the extent, the payment by the Fund to the Investment Adviser of the Expense Waiver would cause the Fund's Net Investment Income to fall below zero, such payment shall not be deferred to a later date.
perturbation.explanation: The original text says that the Investment Advisor has the option to recover the 'full amount' of the Expense Waiver, while the modified text restricts this to only 25% of the amount. This impacts the terms of financial reimbursements and alters the compensation expectations between the parties. Additionally, it limits the recovery of waived expenses to a one-year window, and does not defer payments to ensure positive Net Investment Income.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Investment Company Act of 1940 provisions pertaining to advisory fee structures, expense reimbursements, and fair compensation. This limits the Investment Advisor's reimbursements in a way that is contrary to the parties' financial agreement.
